summary: The case of Ankwandah v. Gwira State Council, decided on April 28, 1956, by the Supreme Court of the Gold Coast, addressed the jurisdiction of State Councils under the State Councils (Colony and Southern Togoland) Ordinance, c. 8 of 1952. The applicant was fined £20 by the Gwira State Council for failing to attend destoolment proceedings, which the Council claimed was an offence under section 26 of the Ordinance and also a breach of native customary law. The applicant sought certiorari to quash the conviction, arguing the Council lacked jurisdiction. The court held that the Council had no authority to convict in criminal matters under section 26, as the Ordinance did not confer such jurisdiction. It further ruled that even if the matter were constitutional, the imposition of a fine was impermissible under section 9, which prohibits State Councils from imposing fines. The application for certiorari succeeded, and the conviction and fine were quashed.
verdict: The application for certiorari was granted and the conviction was quashed.

rationaleHighlights: State Councils lack jurisdiction over criminal offences under the Ordinance.
Section 26 violation is a criminal, not constitutional, matter.
Section 5(3) allows procedural use of native customary law but not adjudication of offences under it.
Section 9 prohibits State Councils from imposing fines.
The penalty imposed was a fine, not a customary award.
Certiorari is appropriate to quash proceedings beyond jurisdiction.
Destoolment is constitutional, but non-attendance is not.
Jurisdictional limits must be strictly observed by administrative bodies.
